From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

Catalan

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Latin picāre (“smear with pitch”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): (Central, Balearic) [pəˈɣa]
  • IPA(key): (Valencia) [peˈɣaɾ]
  • Audio (Barcelona):(file)
  • Homophone: pagar

Verb

[edit]

pegar (first-person singular present pego, first-person singular preterite peguí, past participle pegat); root stress: (Central) /ɛ/; (Valencia, Balearic) /e/

  1. (intransitive) to hit (in order to harm) [with a ‘someone’]
    Per què li pegueu a aquest noi? ― Why are you hitting this boy?
  2. (intransitive, dialectal) to hit [with de ‘something’ and a ‘against something else’]
    Synonyms: topar, xocar
    Vaig pegar de cap a la paret ― I hit my head against the wall
  3. (transitive, dialectal) to give (someone) [with cop ‘knock’, empenta ‘shove’, etc.]
    Synonyms: donar un cop, donar una empenta, empènyer
    Li va pegar una empenta ― He shoved her
  4. (transitive, dialectal) to do [with bot ‘jump’, salt ‘jump’, etc.]
    Synonyms: donar un bot/salt, fer un bot/salt, saltar
    Va pegar un bot ― He jumped
  5. (transitive, dialectal) to throw [with rabinadura ‘tantrum’, etc.]; to show (sudden emotion)
    Synonym: agafar
    Li va pegar una rabinadura al mig de la plaça ― He threw a tantrum in the middle of the square
  6. (dialectal) to glue
    Synonyms: enganxar, encolar

Usage notes

[edit]
  • Words like "to jump", "to shove", "to knock" can be expressed in two ways. The first is with simple verbs (saltar, empènyer, pegar). The second is to use the construction with a verb roughly meaning "to do" plus indefinite article plus substantive (fer un salt / donar un salt / pegar un salt, donar una empenta / pegar una empenta, donar un cop / pegar un cop).

Related terms

[edit]
  • apegar
  • pega
  • pegar-se un toc a la barra

Further reading

[edit]
  • “pegar”, in Diccionari de la llengua catalana [Dictionary of the Catalan Language] (in Catalan), second edition, Institute of Catalan Studies [Catalan: Institut d'Estudis Catalans], April 2007
  • “pegar”, in Gran Diccionari de la Llengua Catalana, Grup Enciclopèdia Catalana, 2025
  • “pegar” in Diccionari normatiu valencià, Acadèmia Valenciana de la Llengua.
  • “pegar” in Diccionari català-valencià-balear, Antoni Maria Alcover and Francesc de Borja Moll, 1962.

Galician

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • apegar

Etymology

[edit]

From Old Galician-Portuguese pegar (att. 14th c.), from Latin picāre (“smear with pitch”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /peˈɣaɾ/

Verb

[edit]

pegar (first-person singular present pego, first-person singular preterite peguei, past participle pegado)

  1. (transitive) to glue
    Synonym: colar
  2. (transitive) to adhere
    Synonym: adherir
  3. (transitive) to fix in place; to hold, steady
    Synonym: fixar
  4. (transitive) to hold, steady
    Synonym: termar
  5. (transitive) to join, splice
    Synonyms: unir, xuntar
  6. (transitive) to hit, blow
    Synonyms: golpear, zoupar
  7. (pronominal) to come closer; to stick
    Synonym: achegar
  8. (transitive) to infect; pass on; infect (a disease)
    Synonym: contaxiar
  9. (transitive, informal) to do; take; have (a kind of catch-all verb for various actions)
    Synonym: dar

Related terms

[edit]
  • pegamazo
  • pegamento

Indonesian

[edit]

Noun

[edit]

pegar (plural pegar-pegar)

  1. pheasant
    Synonym: kuau

Malay

[edit]

Noun

[edit]

pegar (plural pegar-pegar or pegar2)

  1. pheasant
    Synonyms: kuau, kuang

Occitan

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Latin picāre (“smear with pitch”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • Audio (Béarn):(file)

Verb

[edit]

pegar

  1. to glue (attach using glue)
    Synonym: empegar

Portuguese

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Latin picāre (“smear with pitch”), from pix (“pitch”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
 
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /peˈɡa(ʁ)/ [peˈɡa(h)]
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /peˈɡa(ʁ)/ [peˈɡa(h)]
    • (São Paulo) IPA(key): /peˈɡa(ɾ)/
    • (Rio de Janeiro) IPA(key): /peˈɡa(ʁ)/ [peˈɡa(χ)]
    • (Southern Brazil) IPA(key): /peˈɡa(ɻ)/
 
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /pɨˈɡaɾ/ [pɨˈɣaɾ]
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /pɨˈɡaɾ/ [pɨˈɣaɾ]
    • (Southern Portugal) IPA(key): /pɨˈɡa.ɾi/ [pɨˈɣa.ɾi]

  • (Northeast Brazil) IPA(key): /pɛˈɡa(h)/
  • (Rural Central Brazil) IPA(key): /piˈɡa(ɹ)/
  • Audio (Portugal (Porto)):(file)
  • Hyphenation: pe‧gar

Verb

[edit]

pegar (first-person singular present pego, first-person singular preterite peguei, past participle pegado, short past participle pego)

  1. (transitive) to catch
    1. to grab, hold
      Synonym: agarrar
    2. (Brazil) to discover someone doing something
  2. (intransitive) to pick up [with em]
  3. (Brazil, slang, transitive, reflexive) to engage in a romantic and/or sexual relationship with someone for one night or some short period of time
  4. (Brazil, colloquial, transitive, reflexive) to fight, to beat up, to engage in a physical conflict
    Eu vou te pegar na porrada!
    I'm going to beat you up!
  5. (transitive, intransitive) to stick, to glue
    • Fernando Tordo (1973), “Tourada”, (in Portuguese): “E só ficam os peões de brega / Cuja profissão não pega ― And only the peões de brega are left / whose profession doesn't stick”
    Synonym: colar
  6. (colloquial, intransitive) to catch on
  7. (Brazil, transitive) to catch, to take (a transport)
    Vamos pegar um ônibus. ― Let's take a bus.
    Synonyms: apanhar, tomar
  9. (intransitive) to start an engine, vehicle
    O carro não pega! ― The car won't start!
  10. (reflexive) to catch a disease
    Tu pegaste-me COVID! ― I caught COVID from you!
  11. (reflexive, impersonal) to be contagious (of a disease)
    Isso pega-se? ― Is that contagious?
  12. (intransitive, agriculture) to catch, take root

Usage notes

[edit]

The short past participle form pego is mostly used in Brazilian Portuguese.

Descendants

[edit]
  • Macanese: pegâ

Spanish

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Latin picāre (“smear with pitch”), derived from pix (“pitch”). Compare English pitch.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /peˈɡaɾ/ [peˈɣ̞aɾ]
  • Audio (Colombia):(file)
  • Rhymes: -aɾ
  • Syllabification: pe‧gar

Verb

[edit]

pegar (first-person singular present pego, first-person singular preterite pegué, past participle pegado)

  1. (intransitive) to stick
    No pega a la pared
    It doesn't stick to the wall.
  2. (intransitive) to match; to fit; to go with
    La mesa no pega con la silla.
    The table doesn't go with the chair.
  3. (intransitive) to be strong or bright (said of the sun or light)
    Hoy pega mucho el sol.
    The sun is blazing down today.
  4. (computing, transitive) to paste
    copia y pega ― copy and paste
  5. (transitive) to glue
    Pégalo con el pegamento
    Glue it with the glue
  6. (transitive) to hit; strike
    pega el balón ― hit the ball
  7. (transitive) to give; dish out (a strike)
    ¡Te voy a pegar un manotazo!
    I'm gonna give you a slap!
  8. (transitive) to infect; pass on; infect (a disease)
    Creo que me pegó la sífilis.
    I think he gave me syphilis.
  9. (transitive, informal) to do; take; have (a kind of catch-all verb for various actions)
    Synonym: dar
    Voy a pegarme una ducha.
    I'm going to take a shower.
    Aquí falta pegar una buena limpieza.
    This place needs (to have) a good clean-up.
    Pegamos una buena comida.
    We had an awesome lunch
    Acaba de pegar otro grito.
    She's just let out another shout
    ¡No te pegues otra borrachera!
    Don't get smashed again!
    pegar un tiro; pegarse un tiro ― to shoot; to shoot oneself
  10. (colloquial) to flirt, hit on
    Synonyms: coquetear, flirtear, pinchar
  11. (colloquial, Mexico, Central America) to be intoxicating (of alcohol)
    Este tequila te pega mucho.
    This tequila hits you hard.
  12. (reflexive, intransitive) to stick, to become attached, to adhere
  13. (reflexive, intransitive) to take root

1Mostly obsolete, now mainly used in legal language.
2Argentine and Uruguayan voseo prefers the tú form for the present subjunctive.
